message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings, including ecchymoses of the flanks, absence of bowel sounds, and tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding, suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage. The x-ray shows uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels, ruling out small bowel obstruction. Spinal cord injury and acute mesenteric ischemia are less likely causes given the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including severe pain in the right flank, muscle spasms, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal bloating suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage. The ecchymoses and tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding also support this diagnosis. The x-ray of the abdomen showing uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels does not support small bowel perforation, and there is no evidence of spinal cord injury or acute mesenteric ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ecchymoses following the course of a seatbelt, severe pain in the right flank, and absence of bowel sounds suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which can compress the bowel and cause symptoms similar to small bowel perforation or mesenteric ischemia. The x-ray showing uniform gas distribution without air-fluid levels suggests no obstruction or perforation in the bowel. Spinal cord injuries usually present with neurological symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe flank pain, muscle spasms, nausea, vomiting, abdominal bloating, ecchymoses over the abdominal wall and flanks, absent bowel sounds, and tenderness with guarding suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage. The x-ray showing obliteration of the right psoas shadow and uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels further supports this diagnosis. Small bowel perforation would show air-fluid levels in the x-ray, spinal cord injury would not explain the abdominal symptoms, and acute mesenteric ischemia would have abnormal laboratory findings such as an elevated lactate level or abnormal arterial blood gas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of ecchymoses over the flanks and anterior abdominal wall in a pattern that follows the course of a seatbelt and tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with voluntary guarding suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Small bowel perforation would have more localized tenderness and bowel sounds would be hyperactive. Spinal cord injury would not cause nausea and vomiting or absence of bowel sounds. Acute mesenteric ischemia would have severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and bloody stool, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple ecchymoses, tenderness to palpation in all four quadrants with guarding, and an x-ray showing obliteration of the right psoas shadow. All of these suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Small bowel perforation would show air-fluid levels, spinal cord injury would not explain the abdominal symptoms, and acute mesenteric ischemia would show ischemic changes in the bowel.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe pain in the right flank, abdominal bloating, absent bowel sounds, and tenderness to palpation with voluntary guarding, suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage. The x-ray of the abdomen shows uniform distribution of gas in the small bowel, colon, and rectum without air-fluid levels, ruling out small bowel perforation and acute mesenteric ischemia. Spinal cord injury does not typically cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage, due to the seatbelt sign, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and hemoglobin level. The obliteration of the right psoas shadow on the x-ray also supports this diagnosis. Small bowel perforation and acute mesenteric ischemia would cause air-fluid levels on x-ray, and spinal cord injury would not explain the abdominal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which is confirmed by the x-ray showing obliteration of the right psoas shadow. The absence of air-fluid levels on the x-ray suggests no bowel perforation or obstruction. There is also no indication of spinal cord injury or acute mesenteric ischemia. Further imaging studies and treatment, such as transfusion and surgical intervention, may be necessary for managing retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the imaging findings suggest retroperitoneal hemorrhage, which often occurs as a result of a blunt injury to the abdomen or back. Small bowel perforation would present with air-fluid levels on x-ray, while spinal cord injury or acute mesenteric ischemia would not explain the ecchymoses and abdominal tenderness.
